baseline_groups.claim_summary: Workers on online gig platforms earn positive markup relative to their minimum willingness to accept (WTA), with mean markup > 1.
baseline_groups.notes: Unweighted ~1.24 (24% markup); IPW-weighted ~1.38. Both means of hourly surplus ratio.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Workers earn positive markup relative to their ex-post willingness to accept, with mean markup > 1.
baseline_groups.notes: Unweighted ~1.16 (16% markup); IPW-weighted ~1.15. Ex-post WTA based on actual job experience.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Workers earn positive markup relative to their outside wage, with mean markup > 1.
baseline_groups.notes: Unweighted ~1.50 (50% markup); IPW-weighted ~1.23. Smaller sample (n=46) due to missing outside wage.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Workers earn positive markup on fixed-price contracts relative to ex-post WTA, with mean markup > 1.
baseline_groups.notes: Unweighted ~1.87 (87% markup); IPW-weighted ~1.62. Largest markups. n=99 fixed-price contracts.

global_notes: This paper estimates worker surplus as ratios (wage/WTA) where >1 indicates positive surplus. The treatment_var is coded as mean_surplus for baselines, which is descriptive (not causal regression). spec_ids baseline and baseline_weighted are reused across groups (distinguished by outcome_var). Control variation and OLS predictor specs change treatment to log_numjobs etc., testing different estimands. Heterogeneity specs also use different treatments (c_US, high_experience). Sample restriction and tercile splits are borderline between core_sample and noncore_heterogeneity but are classified as core because they compute the same mean surplus in subsamples rather than testing interaction effects.
